items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
AB 1417 requires all California community college boards of trustees to annually review and officially accept performance measurement data for their colleges that is included in the Student Success Scorecard Report. The report, which the State Chancellor’s Office provides to the state legislature, contains performance measures for each college.
	 
The purpose of the report is to encourage colleges to improve their student success-related outcomes over time. Interim Executive Director of Institutional Research Mallory Newell will present the 2014 Student Success Scorecard for Foothill College and De Anza College.
	 
Since several scorecard measures are included as District Strategic Plan metrics, the presentation will include progress on the metrics as outlined in the District Strategic Plan.
	 
 The governing board will be asked to consider approval of the performance measurement data during the regular meeting.
	 
Submitted by:
Mallory Newell
Additional contact names:
Joe Moreau
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 2712 (formerly 9200) Conflict of Interest Code was presented for first reading at the August 4, 2014, meeting. Under the Political Reform Act, the district is required to review its conflict of interest code every even-numbered year, and policy amendments must be approved both by the district's Board of Trustees and the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors. Revisions to the policy language were recommended by the Santa Clara Office of the County Counsel to clarify disclosure requirements and ensure compliance with recent decisions by the Fair Political Practices Commission. In addition, the policy has been updated to reflect position title changes as well as new positions created in connection with the Online Education Initiative grant.
	 
The Santa Clara County Counsel's office has provided preliminary approval of the proposed amended code, and it was approved electronically by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on July 25, 2014. Once the governing board has adopted the revisions, the policy will be submitted to the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors for final approval.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends adoption of revised board policy 2712 Conflict of Interest Code.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The purpose of a Valley Transportation Authority (VTA) EcoPass agreement is to provide annual transit passes to all eligible students of Foothill-De Anza Community College District. 
	 
At the De Anza College Student Body election on May 15, 2011, a majority of students agreed that the Foothill De Anza Community College District Board of Trustees should take action to charge a mandatory quarterly fee of up to five dollars to all full-time De Anza College students and a mandatory quarterly prorated fee to all De Anza College part-time students to make VTA EcoPasses available to all De Anza students. On June 20, 2011, the Board of Trustees passed a resolution implementing the mandatory transportation fee effective fall quarter 2011 at De Anza College.
	 
At the Foothill Student Body election January 28-31, 2013, a majority of students (1112 out of 1333 students voting) agreed that the Foothill-De Anza Community College District Board of Trustees should take action to charge a mandatory quarterly fee of up to five dollars to all full-time Foothill College students and a mandatory prorated fee to all Foothill College part-time students to make a VTA EcoPass available to all students.  On March 11, 2013, the Board of Trustees passed a resolution implementing the mandatory fee. 
	 
Board approval is requested for the 2014-2015 VTA EcoPass contract (September 22, 2014 - September 25, 2015) for an estimated amount of $342,000.
	 
Submitted by:
Brian Murphy, President De Anza College, ext 8705 &  Judy Miner, President, Foothill College x7200
Additional contact names:
Donna Jones Dulin Interim VP, Finance & College Operations ext 8209 & Bernata Slater VP, Institutional Resources ext 7364
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College President Brian Murphy and Foothill College President Judy Miner recommend approval of the VTA EcoPass contract to provide annual transit passes to Foothill-De Anza Community College District students for an estimated $342,000 for the academic year 2014-2015.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Pursuant to Foothill-De Anza Community College District Board Policy 3205 (attached), the use of college facilities by outside groups shall be for short-term, temporary needs. 
	 
Facility uses that may be long in duration, that represent an exclusive use, or that are for commercial purposes not covered by the civic center provisions of the Education Code or this policy must be presented and approved by the Board of Trustees prior to occupancy.
	 
Los Altos Mountain View Aquatic Club (LAMVAC) has a long-standing relationship with Foothill College and has been renting Foothill College's pool for the past 50 years.  In order to afford LAMVAC sufficient time to prepare for an adjustment in a proposed increase in rates in FY 2015-16, Foothill College is requesting the following:
	 
1)       One year contract for the use of Foothill pool at requested hours
2)       Rate of $4,000 per month 
	 
Submitted by:
Bernata Slater, Vice President, Finance and Administrative Resources, Foothill College
Additional contact names:
Susan Traynor, Facilities Rental Coordinator, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College recommends approval.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
De Anza College is requesting approval of grant writing, submission and implementation services from Dowden Associates to develop, submit, and implement grants for Title III and AANAPISI Part A. De Anza College has had a successful grant writing relationship with Dowden Associates which resulted in the award of two previous AANAPISI grants and one previous Title III grant.
	 
De Anza College may only be awarded with a Title III grant or an AANAPISI Part A grant. The College cannot be awarded both grants.  De Anza College will only be responsible for paying Dowden Associates for the fees of whichever grant is funded.
	 
Both grants are for a five year period. The Title III grant annual award amount is between $400,000 and $450,000 (5-year max. total of $2.25M). The annual consultant fee payable to Dowden Associates, if this grant is funded, is $30,000. The AANAPISI Part A grant annual award amount is  $300,000 (5-year max. total of $1.5M). The annual consultant fee payable to Dowden Associates, if this grant is funded, is $20,000.
	 
Consultant fees related to the application of these grants cannot be paid by the grant award. These costs, if a grant is successfully awarded, will be paid from the general fund.
	 
Submitted by:
De Anza College President Brian Murphy, ext 8706
Additional contact names:
De Anza College Associate Vice President Instruction Rowena Tomaneng, ext 8510
Is backup provided?
yes
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College President Brian Murphy recommends approval of Dowden Associates MOUs for Title III and AANAPISI Part A Grants

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 4225 (formerly 6124) regarding limits on course repetition to alleviate a grade for substandard academic work is attached for first reading. The language in the policy, which conforms to regulations set forth in Title 5, has been changed to be consistent with college publications and related policies and procedures.  In addition, a reference has been added to the administrative procedure regarding credit course adds, drops, and withdrawals, and the policy number has been changed to align with the Community College League of California's Policy and Procedure Service numbering system. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, while deleted text is represented by strikethrough. 
	 
The policy revisions were approved by the Academic and Professional Matters Committee on January 17, 2014, and by the Chancellor's Advisory Council electronically on March 14, 2014. The revised policy will be presented for governing board adoption on September 8, 2014.
	 
References:
Title 5, Sections 55024, 55040, 55041, 55042, 55043, 55044, 58161
Education Code Section 76224
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Student trustee Epps was unable to attend the regular Board meeting of August 4, 2014, due to illness.  As stated in Education Code ยง72024(d):
	 
A member may be paid for any meeting when absent if the board, by resolution duly adopted and included in its minutes, finds that, at the time of the meeting, he or she is performing services outside the meeting for the community college district, he or she was ill or on jury duty, or the absence was due to a hardship deemed acceptable by the board. The compensation shall be a charge against the funds of the district.
	 
Included for adoption by the Board is a resolution verifying the circumstances of trustee Epps' absence as required by Education Code Section 72024(d).
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor 
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends approval of the resolution authorizing student trustee Melissa Epps' absence from the August 4, 2014, Board of Trustees meeting.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Provisions with SB 564 require local agencies to report all external investments on a quarterly basis.  In accordance with the aforementioned requirement, attached is a listing of the District's investments as of June 30, 2014.
	 
The District's cash, in the amount of $213,151,843.32, is invested in the County's Commingled Investments Pool.  As of June 30, 2014, the current yield on the commingled investments pool was 0.46%.  As a comparison to the same time period, the yield on a two-year Treasury Note was 0.46%; the yield on a 6-month Treasury Bill was 0.06%; and the State of California Local Agency Investment Fund (LAIF) yield was 0.23%. 
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
Is backup provided?
 Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Representatives from the district's General Obligation Bond underwriters, Morgan Stanley, and the district's bond sale financial advisor, William Euphrat, will present a closing summary report of the July 2014 sale of the refunding general obligation bonds (of bonds originally issued and sold as authorized by passage of the district's 1999 Measure E and 2006 Measure C General Obligation Bond elections).  The District successfully sold $103,015,000 refunding general obligation bonds producing total savings of $12.2 million to District taxpayers.
	 
Proceeds of the bonds will be used to pay for the advance refunding of a portion of the District's outstanding Election of 1999 General Obligation Bonds, Series C, Election of 2006 General Obligation Bonds, Series A and B, and the payment of costs of issuance of the Bonds.  The net proceeds of the Bonds will be deposited into an escrow fund and applied to pay the principal of and interest on the refunding bonds as they become due and to pay redemption prices on the refunded bonds at their respective next available redemption dates.
	 
The refunding will reduce debt service through 2036 by an annual average of $553,914.  These savings will result in a tax rate reduction of approximately $0.49/$100,000 of current assessed value.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 John Sheldon, Morgan Stanley, William Euphrat, Financial Advisor
Is backup provided?
 Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In accordance with Title 5 Section 58301, the governing board is required to hold a public hearing on the adoption of the 2014-15 proposed budget of the District for the year ending June 30, 2015.  The board will be asked to officially adopt the budget at its meeting on September 8, 2014.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6201
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
 Joni Hayes, Director, Budget Operations, x6261
Is backup provided?

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District agreed in 2007 to create a Post-97 Fund dedicated to a post-age-65 retiree benefit for District employees hired after July 1, 1997.  By agreement, the Post-97 Fund shall not increase the Districtâs Other Post-Employment Benefits (OPEB) unfunded liability. 
	 
The Post-97 Fund shall be established with the previously negotiated FA Post-1997 Health Benefits Reserve ($250,000), the ACE Post-1997 Health Benefits Reserve ($250,000), and $500,000 from District Fund 600.  In addition, for the 2013, 2014, and 2015 Plan Years, the District will contribute to the Post 97 Fund the equivalent of: $2 employee-only; $4 employee-plus-one; and $6 employee-plus-family; based on employee and retiree enrollment each year.  Future funding may continue subject to negotiations. 
	 
The District and Unions have worked together for nearly two years, with input from other members of the Joint Labor Management Benefits Council (JLMBC) and legal counsel specializing in Benefit Trust preparation, to create an appropriate Post-97 Fund, now called the VEBA Trust for Retirees of FHDA and its formal Trust Agreement for this purpose. Discussions and deliberations have focused on determining its structure, governance, fiduciary obligations, administration and funding provisions.
	 
Attached is the final document that defines the terms of the VEBA Trust and serves as the legal document to establish the VEBA Trust as a tax-exempt trust under Section 501(c)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code, also known as a Voluntary Employeesâ Beneficiary Association (VEBA) trust.
	 
Submitted by:
Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources & Equal Opportunity x6211
Additional contact names:
N/A
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and Equal Opportunity, recommends approval.
items.item_text: VEBA Trust Agreement (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 23. VEBA Trust Agreement (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The approved VEBA Trust for Retirees of FHDA requires persons to be appointed by the District Board of Trustees to manage the operation and administration, and receive, hold, invest and distribute the assets of the Trust, acting under the provisions of the Trust Agreement.  Incumbents in the following District positions shall serve as the officially appointed District Trustees to serve on the Board of Trustees for the VEBA Trust:
	 
Position
Department
Current Incumbent
·         Vice Chancellor, Business Services 
Business Services
Kevin McElroy
·         Executive Director, Fiscal Services
Business Services 
Hector Quinonez
·         Vice Chancellor, Human Resources
Human Resources
Dorene Novotny
·         Director, Human Resources
Human Resources
Charo Albarran
·         Administrative representative of the AMA
AMA Administrators
Donna Jones-Dulin
	 
Submitted by:
Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources & Equal Opportunity x6211
Additional contact names:
N/A
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and Equal Opportunity, recommends approval.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Change Order #6
Vendor:  Alten Construction
Agreement Date:  October 17, 2013
Campus:  Foothill College
Project Number:  420
Project Name:  District Office Building Renovation
Amount:  $163,986.00
For:
	 
Framing changes due to site conditions and changes in use for ETS, and modification of the building fire water main line due to site conditions and requirements of the local fire marshal.
	 
This change order also includes the cost of structural repairs to the central high roof due to dry rot damage to existing structural beams.  Authorization to negotiate and approve a change order in excess of $50,000, not to exceed $200,000, was approved by the Board of Trustees on July 7, 2014 to allow this work to continue in a timely manner.  
	 
That authorization has allowed the work, at a cost of $133,612, to proceed as quickly as possible, but this change has delayed the project from its original timeline.  Because the delay is concurrent with delays related to re-purpose of the building for use by ETS, time impact costs related to the roof structure repairs will be negotiated and included in a separate change order to resolve all delay issues.  
	 
This change plus all previously approved change orders equal 10.7% of the base contract value.  The cost of this work is within the current project budget.  
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations, extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval
items.item_text: Alten Construction - Change Order #6 - District Office Building Renovation - $163,986.00
items.item_text_raw: A) Alten Construction - Change Order #6 - District Office Building Renovation - $163,986.00
